\documentclass[english]{article}
\usepackage[T1]{fontenc}
\usepackage[latin9]{luainputenc}
\usepackage{geometry}
\geometry{verbose,tmargin=0.75in,bmargin=0.5in,lmargin=0.4in,rmargin=0.4in}
\usepackage{amstext}
\usepackage{amssymb}
\usepackage{babel}
\begin{document}
\title{Math 320 HW 7}
\maketitle

\section*{1)}

\subsection*{a)}

Compute all the elements of $G=C_{2}\times D_{3}$ and $H=C_{2}\times C_{6}$.

\subsection*{b)}

Make a Cayley digraph for $G$ and $H$.

\subsection*{c)}

How many generators do you need to generate $G$ and $H$?

\subsection*{d)}

Are $G$ and $H$ isomorphic?

\section*{2)}

Determine which of the functions $\phi:G\rightarrow H$ below are
homomorphisms. If $\phi$ is a homomorphism, prove it. If $\phi$
isn't a homomorphism, explain why.

\subsection*{a)}

$G=\left(\mathbb{C}^{*},*\right)$, $H=\left(\mathbb{R}^{+},*\right)$,
$\phi\left(z\right)=\left|z\right|$ where $\mathbb{C}^{*}$ is the
set of non-zero complex numbers.

\subsection*{b)}

$G=\left(\mathbb{C},*\right)$, $H=\left(\mathbb{R},+\right)$, $\phi\left(z\right)=\left|z\right|$

\subsection*{c)}

$G=\left(\mathbb{R}^{3},+\right)$, $H=\left(\mathbb{R}^{2},+\right)$,
$\phi\left(\vec{x}\right)=\left(\begin{array}{ccc}
1 & 2 & 3\\
2 & 4 & 6
\end{array}\right)\vec{x}$

\section*{3)}

For each of the functions in \textbf{3)} that are homomorphisms, find
$\text{Ker}\left(\phi\right)$.

\section*{4)}

Suppose $\phi:G\rightarrow H$ is a homomorphism that is onto. Show
that $\phi$ is an isomorphism if and only if $\text{Ker}\left(\phi\right)=\left\{ e_{H}\right\} $.

\section*{5)}

Suppose group $G$ is generated by the elements of $X=\left\{ g_{1},g_{2},\dots,g_{n}\right\} $
and $H$ is generated by the elements of $Y=\left\{ h_{1},h_{2},\dots,h_{m}\right\} $.
Show that $G\times H$ is generated by the elements of  $\left\{ \left(g_{i},e_{h}\right),\left(e_{g},h_{j}\right)|1\leq i\leq n,1\leq j\leq m\right\} $
and where $e_{g},e_{h}$ are the identity elements of $G$ and $H$
respectively.

\section*{6)}

Consider the projection map $\text{proj}_{k}:\times_{i=1}^{n}G_{i}\rightarrow G_{k}$
given by 

\[
\text{proj}_{k}\left(\left(g_{1},g_{2},\dots,g_{n}\right)\right)=g_{k}
\]

This mapping will output the coordinate in a given ordered tuple corresponding
to the $k$th group. Show $\text{proj}_{k}$ is a homomorphism and
find its kernel.  
\end{document}
